description:
Like many other artisanal small coffee shops in San Francisco, except with ice cream!  And that is an excellent differentiator because you don't need to choose between caffeine and a dessert in the afternoon.  Probably not good for a diet, but definitely a nice treat.

Affogato: When you want ice cream, but you put on airs like you're just heading out for a coffee drink.  The ice cream looked like cheap soft serve, but tasted way better than any Mister Softee.  Very creamy and sweet.  The bitter espresso shot was the perfect pairing.  Like a mature adult ice cream float.  And the best part is it turned into a creamy coffee beverage at the end when all the ice cream was either eaten or melted.

Milkshake: Love how they don't even try to pawn this off as coffee beverage that just happens to be high caloric.  Nope, it's a milkshake that's made with ice cream, two espresso shots and some chocolate syrup.  And it's delicious; way tastier than an icy Frappuccino.
author: Adam B.

description:
While this is super cute place and the staff is super nice they overcharge when you want something simple. 
I ordered a large steamed oat milk twice at this place but every time I come in being charged for an espresso drink $3.50 + $1.00 surcharge for oat milk. Why am I being charged for a latte when all I wanted is steamed milk and on top of that being surcharged for the type of milk I want? 
Do yourself a favor and go up the street to Coffee Bar where I got a 16 oz steamed oat milk for $2.00 versus 12 oz steamed oat milk $4.50 
Even if you go to Starbucks and order just a steamed milk they charge you as such. They don't charge you for a latte and give you only streamed milk. 
If you are going there for a latte this place is fabulous but if you want something simple be prepared to pay more than double for not as much product.
Oh yeah and even when you get steamed it's lukewarm.
author: Jen C.

description:
I sat down outside this coffeeshop deliberating on whether to text my friend to meet me here -- the outside seating area was completely empty  -- when a small (as in petty, and stature as well) man in a beard and flat cap came out of the shop to tell me that I couldn't sit there unless I bought a coffee. apparently, things were so slow inside that he was now spending his time shooing off potential customers.

He had, in effect, made my decision for me. If their coffee is anything like their customer service, then I'm fairly certain it's garbage.
author: BG M.

description:
Coffee was strong and delicious, service was fast, and the interior was trendy af. Everything I love when I walk into a coffee shop! 

I came with a coworker for a morning pick me up on a Friday morning and I got the small latte with almond milk. My total was around $5 which was a bit pricey for me but the norm for San Francisco. We were in and out of there in less than 5 minutes! 

The coffee itself is delicious (especially with almond milk, trust me!). I do wish there were a few more things on their menus, but I do appreciate the simplicity of it since they seem to do what they know well. 

This shop is a bit cramped inside so I wouldn't recommend stopping to get work done or anything. To me, it's very much so a grab your coffee and go kind of place. Overall, I'd definitely come back!
author: Christine W.

description:
This place was my favorite coffee shop last time. They had great croissant that is very flaky, buttery, and tasty. (I think they are from Jane The Bakery) Today I went there to get my almond croissant, and was surprised to get a soft texture croissant that tasted like it was made a couple days before. 

I talked to the barista, and she told me to return the croissant (really?) She did not expressed any concern at all about the poor quality croissant and keep insisting me on returning it. 

Okay, I'm not going back there again
author: Joan A.

description:
I love this place! 
And the caramel cappuccino was delicious. 
I highly recommend this place. I had my coffee and I worked on my computer just on the middle of the city! 
Love it!
author: Verónica B.

description: Hip and convenient little coffee shop in the FiDi. There isn't much seating inside (a few seats at the window) and a couple of small tables outside, so it's a better grab and go type of place. It's pretty pricey for what it is, all things considered, but it's also pretty standard pricing for trendy coffee places in the FiDi.
author: Grace P.

description: Just like every other 1-star review on here, I too had a problem with their horrible staff.  I'm 7 months pregnant and took a seat outside this establishment, where zero other people were sitting, to catch a break. I had every intention of purchasing a drink when the same short hispanic guy with a flat cap (mentioned in other reviews) told me to leave, not once, but twice.  When I told him I was going to buy something, his response was "I DON'T CARE." It's because of a$$holes like you that hate spreads rampantly across this nation.
author: Lei C.

description: I thought I'd try their mocha and when I asked for whipped cream was told they didn't have any, but wait...I thought I had seen someone with whip in their coffee. Well I was mistaken it was soft serve! On a beautiful day in the city what better way to get your afternoon coffee fix than an aboragado (sp?) Soft serve! Way better than a mocha and oh so good! Can't wait until my office sends me tonSF again!
author: R L.

description:
Good coffee but unwelcoming culture. A co-worker and I (with his laptop in hand) walked in having a technical conversation. We were there for a minute then the manager suddenly interrupted our conversation because we were being rude. He said we were ignoring the baristas when they were saying "hi" to us. Ok I understand that was rude of us but we didn't know because we were having a deep conversation (we were in the zone). The manager also said that it was rude of us for using Target's free wi-fi in their coffee shop (Target is right next to them and Target happen to have free wi-fi available). Didn't really understand that situation but ok, we decided to step outside and carry on our conversation since it seems like we were causing some sort of trouble to them. 

According to their website "Our team and our customers matter. We are passionate about creating connections with our baristas and making each visit better than expected." Well that visit certainly was not any better. And the fact that we had to step outside because we didn't really matter to them. They may have good coffee but unwelcoming culture.
author: Mike L.

description: Good espresso, good baked goods. The location is small, but cute. I'm only ever here in the morning and I find that the line moves quickly. I did not find the service to be rude like other yelpers - nobody smiles at you or pretends to be your best friend, but I don't really need that to enjoy my coffee.
author: Nelya T.

description:
Was waiting for my boyfriend to get on his lunch break, so I decided to step into this coffee shop located a block away. Upon entering, the place is cute, small, and yet has a decent amount of seating along a bar faced to the window where one can sip coffee and people watch. I noticed that they roast their own coffee beans which is neat. Not sure if that have other locations elsewhere. I appreciate a coffee shop that create their own foundation for the coffee they serve. Got a cappuccino, and it was a served with intricate latte art in a cute paper cup. It was a nice cup of coffee. That's about the best description I can give. 
The service was alright. They didn't seem to really care that I came in to purchase coffee or not.
author: Kim N.

description: This place is really close to work and when I showed up early the other day decided to sit at their cute little window counter and enjoy a macchiato. They serve it small which I enjoy cause you get a good flavor from the coffee that way. The two ladies working were efficient and friendly. The line got long and they got through orders very well. They also have soft serve which is pretty cool!
author: Shelby L.

description: Great coffee. They sell beans for $15 or $17. I love the coffee bean packaging because it has an air seal thing that lets you smell the coffee so well. They smell so good. This is a quaint shop with a large window and window seats.
author: Gloria T.

description:
Literally had the most rude experience. I was waiting for a friend before deciding what to drink together and of course the barista manages to come over as she's untying her ponytail to ask if I was waiting for someone. Then proceeds to say in the snarkiest way "Order before they get here." 

I would always understand that people have to do this to prevent people from sitting at the shop without ordering anything, but I've never had someone come up to say it to me in that way (or ever). Especially if I didn't have a computer and clearly didn't look like I was about to say stick around for a long time without ordering. 

Needless to say, I'm never coming back.
author: My N.

description:
Quaint little coffee shop located in the heart of Fidi. If you're looking for a nice cup of coffee to catch up with a friend, this is the perfect location to meet up at. While seats are limited, there's always a seat or two for you and your friend to sit at. 

Not exactly the most ideal place to study/ get work done for the music is a little too loud. But the baristas are super nice and the location is literally a 1 minute walk away from Montgomery Station. Would definitely recommend to friends.
author: Leah C.

description: Expensive coffee really isn't my thing but if it's your's, you will probably like this place. It was $5.25 for a mocha plus $1 extra for almond milk. The coffee tastes good but I've had better elsewhere. I didn't taste the chocolate much but it is pretty. The cafe is hip and modern with tables outside. You can't really hang out inside even standing because it's a pretty tight place. The service is OK. They aren't very friendly. I went at 9:50am so it wasn't busy. There were two people ahead of me waiting for coffee and one person after me.
author: Jen L.

description:
Aesthetically trendy. Acoustically echoey (probably a high ceiling). Mediocre mocha and pour over. 

C O F F E E: 

1 mocha
1 pour over

Mocha definitely didn't have a good blend of both chocolate and coffee that I was expecting. Tasted like a foam of lightly hinted coffee and lots of milk. 

Pourover was decent. Slightly more enjoyable than the mocha. Though it was a medium roasted coffee, the name wasn't memorable since it sounded very hipster with a touch of third world. Not what I expected from a highly rated coffee shop in the FiDi.

S E R V I C E: 

Seemed straight and to the point. No enthusiastic morning greeting or small chatter. It was like "what you want"? Orders. Got my drink. Sat around for a bit to observe. 

If you're not dressed like a business guy or a techy, they won't be friendly enough to talk to you. 

Not coming back.
author: Jason C. J.

description:
Came here early this week for the first time and was impressed with their set up. Not to mention they've combined frozen yogurt, coffee, and espresso. I saw affogato on the menu and got super excited (will have to come back and try that). There's nothing better than froyo/ice cream and espresso - nothing!

We got a couple of iced cold brews, which we're great! Will be back :)
author: Fahren F.

description: SMOOTHEST Chai Latte you've ever had. I have tried chai lattes in multiple locations around the area and will definitely not be going back to any of those after tasting heaven.
author: Maria Catalina S.

description:
Lately I've been on a quest to find the best cup of coffee. Coffee Culture is just around the block from my office. It's caught my eye a few times, so I finally decided to check it out. 

Stopped by around 9:30ish. The lines weren't too bad. It's a small space so even if the line is out the door it tends to move quickly. 

So far I've tried the almond milk latte and a variety of their "Coffee of the Day." 12oz is just $2.75. 

Im kind of obsessed with the vibe in here. The atmosphere here is quite chill and relaxed (unlike workshop coffee). They play a lot of hip hop here which has totally hooked me into coming here more often than any other cafe. Ambience is important y'all! 

Btw...they have soft serve! I haven't had a chance to try it yet, but it's definitely on my mind. 

TL;DR-People are friendly. Love the window bar seating. Coffee of the day-changes daily obvi. Great environment.
author: Dianna C.

description:
It's a great location for me as it's under my office and also has great coffee!

The lines are generally short lines and there's good service.
author: Alys M.

description: Having been in customer service management for 25 years, I'll admit to having fairly high standards when I'm out and about as a customer. Having said that, I am also flexible and understanding when the person helping me is very busy. I just came from Coffee Cultures on Bush St. It's been a long time since I've had such truly unfriendly, rude and aloof service. It was not busy. There was only one person ahead of me who purchased a drip coffee and left. There was no queue of drinks for the barrista.  With a smile I said, "Good morning. How are you?" I received nothing in response outside of an annoyed expression of impatience. Awkward moment...so I just proceeded to order a drink and a pastry and paid, leaving a 24% tip and a sincere thank you. I got a mumbled "mmhm" without eye contact. It seemed that making fun of a street performer outside was more important than being professional and friendly to paying customers. I received my drink, which I will say looked beautiful, and again I expressed my gratitude. The barrista responded with a barely audible "yeah, thanks" with no eye contact. She seemed eager to return to the conversation with the cashier that I apparently, so rudely, interrupted. My drink is great but it's the last one I will purchase at Coffee Cultures as I will not be back. As much as I enjoy the product, I can't support or recommend a business that encourages the kind of behavior I encountered today.
author: Sean H.

description: The coffee they serve get's an A-...that is, it's excellent. To me, the coffee is more pure than Philz and I've been drinking Philz almost everyday for a year now. That being said, the coffee is fairly overpriced...basically a quarter or so cheaper than Philz. Also, within a block of this place, you have Blue Bottle, Illy, Philz, Starbucks, and Pete's. I can't really find a compelling argument why you'd pick this place over the others, but it's a nice change of pace.
author: Daniel F.

description:
I think it's cool that Coffee Cultures is the only coffee place that has soft serve AND high quality coffee drinks in the same shop. I  was amazed at their soft serve when the barista handed me a sample of their horchata mixed with chocolate. SO good! I can see how an affogato or milkshake would taste really good with that combination!

The only drinks I've tried here are their lattes, which are pretty good. For $4 a pop, what can you expect as you're already in the heart of the financial district and have blue bottle across the street & coffee bar around the corner & starbucks next door in Target competing for the coffee addict's business. Next time I come here I'm definitely having more of their soft serve especially if and when SF gets nice and hot (one can only hope..)
author: Kathleen S.

description:
I will repeat the advice kindly given to me by their glorified coffee maker:

"Don't ever come back here again!" 

And, I say, if you've never been, "Never go there!"

I chose this place since the line Blue Bottle seemed insane at around 3:00pm, and it was pretty empty here. I waited patiently for my latte and got a little concerned when a half hour was approaching, and my latte was still not done. I checked in but was dismissed. 

When a group of four who definitely came after me received all of their orders before me, I was dismayed and expressed this to their glorified coffee maker who promptly responded that I should never go back there again. 

Ok, easy. I never will! I will also make sure no one else I know, or have any communications with, will ever step foot in your establishment. Good luck surviving in a coffee shop saturated city!
author: Kat M.

description:
I used to work at 225 Bush St but never came to Coffee Cultures because our co-working space always had coffee. Now that I no longer work in the building, of course it was time to give this place a try... and okay I'll admit that I had been missing out. The baristas are super friendly (especially for 7am) and quickly poured the house coffee I ordered. 

The barista at the cashier totally saw me eyeing the pastries and called me out, so I ended up getting a fruit scone to go with my coffee. Fresh and tasty. I've seen that this place can get packed pretty quickly, so go early if possible!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
It's like the barista's need to drink some of their own coffee.

When I come here for a mid day pick me up, at around 2pm, they always seem to be super slow, even though there are no lines.

I've been here about 4 times and each time the Batista's take forever.

I find their coffee to be too strong for my tastes, but I'm always dragged here by my coworkers so I try not to put up a fight.

There are bigger battles to fight, you know?

Not a huge fan of this place.
author: Jack R.

description: Poor attitude and bad service! And damn slow..want to change? Easy..smile, greet and be polite!!
author: M M.

description:
Coffee: Fair-trade.  Aromatic.  Beautifully roasted.  (Not your typical Pike Place Roast)

Espresso: Probably one of the best I've ever had.  Will jolt you up for the rest of the morning.

Favorite drink: Just a simple latte.  Again, probably one of the best I've ever had.

Favorite pastry: Chocolate croissant.  Toasted.  So buttery and flakey.  YUMMMM

Convenience factor:  Extremely convenient if you are in the FiDi.  Quick service.  You are in and out like *snap* that.

Décor/Space: Lovely.  Has a bit of a rustic charm with high ceilings and dark wood.  Small space though - it's not really a place to hang out and sip your coffee.  Gotta grab and go!

Overall: Love it!
author: Cecilia S.

description:
Honestly, I prefer blue bottle across the street, especially given its gorgeous building and plentiful seating. Coffee Cultures doesn't have nearly as much space - but the baked goods are interesting and the coffee is good. Their PSL is MUCH better than most I've had - I asked for less sweet and they suggested trying half-sweet, and it was GREAT! 
The Straus ice cream is also of interest.
author: Lisa K.

description: Actually one of the best LATTE I had in a long time. Staff was friendly. Their **Almond Croissant is amazing. Not too sweet. Definitely coming back. FYI the drinks does take longer than most coffee places. Not for you if you're in a rush but its really good.
author: Sandy B.

description:
I did a canvas of all the coffee spots in about an 8 block radius of my FiDi office and this is one of the two top spots! In each place I ordered a cappuccino as a control group and then on another visit, a different drink or the specialty of the house. 

Although I wish Coffee Cultures had more spots to sit and enjoy a coffee break, it still is a great spot for a well-made cappuccino and affogato! I admit I haven't strayed from these two orders yet because they're so good, but I believe that if a place can master a cappuccino, the rest of their menu is probably solid, too.
author: Maria Y.

description:
it's a coffee shop, but they have AMAZING soft serve. i just went for the first time today and omg i'm sold. i think i'm going to try an affogato next time.

love its aesthetics and vibe. happy that it's kind of hidden so it's like a hidden gem for people who actually work around the area.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I'll admit, I was captured by the typography. 

After walking in and turning my head from corner to corner of this small coffee joint, I decided on getting an almond milk latte. It didn't come too hot where it would burn my hand and it was just warm enough where I can see myself chug it if need be. But as I was walking with it in my hand, I felt it getting cold within 5-10 minutes. I was happy to quickly indulge it anyway! 

The first sip of the latte was heavenly! And I mean, fluffy angelic clouds of almond milk. It was extremely light to the point where I felt like I could just inhale it. It was sweeter than most almond milks I've ever tried, but I don't have too much of a problem with it. The espresso folded itself into the milk really well making the combination of both irresistible. 

It's a little out of the way, but I would make detours to Coffee Culture any day!
author: Linda K.

description:
Cool hipster coffee spot in fidi - there's a small amount of window seating + outdoor seating (though it seems usually pretty shady here).

- Soy cappuccino: super tasty, smooth espresso, and perfectly warm soy. Almond milk also available (both +$0.50)
- Vanilla frozen yogurt: more icy than creamy, strong vanilla bean flavor and sweet - though not overly overly sweet. Definitely tasty

Pastries + yogurt available, can't wait to come back!
author: Kristie C.

description:
At 10 am, I walked in to see a prominent pour-over menu.  I tried to order from it, but was told they only did pour overs after noon (the sign had no such indication).  I got a drip instead.  It was okay.

Returning at 2:30 pm, I again attempted to order a pour over.  I was told they only do pour overs between noon and 2 pm (again, never indicated).  When I asked why, they said they were short staffed at the moment.  I asked, "Is that normal or just while you're short staffed?"  The barista replied (exasperated that I could possibly question this), "No, it's always that way."  What? I got the okay drip again.

If you're going to advertise something, serve it.  It wasn't a permanent sign--if you're not doing pour overs right now, take the sign down.  And don't be snooty when someone orders from the big menu you put up.
author: Bryan M.

description: The space is easy to get to you and the coffee is strong. Short lines, but limited space. The people are nice. The food wasn't as good as other coffee shops.
author: Laurisha C.

description:
Good coffee, worst customer service EVER. 

Too bad their service sucks or else I would keep going there. The coffee is actually tasty, they have good food on the menu, and what's not to like with the irreverent hipster vibe? 

But really, after being a loyal fan and buying coffee there for a full year (I work IN the building), I go in and try to get a cup and my stupid lame debit card mag strip fails. The guy tries running it a few times, then just hands the card back and says, "not working." 

Seriously? I have been here so many times. You may be new (you are, I know this), but did you even ask your colleague at the next cash register if she could try my card, just to see if that card reader would work? Nope, you could not be bothered. Just, "sorry, no coffee for you."

Did you think to yourself, "maybe I could write her an IOU and give her the coffee, and then ask that she comes back TODAY to pay for it?" Nope. I mean heck, I ordered an Americano, and that's a whopping $2.75. 

Sorry you could not be bothered to give me good service, like I am sure a couple of the dudes there would do. Thanks to you, I will get more exercise going down to the Philz Truck from now on. And I will make sure my colleagues know to do the same!
author: Lisa H.

description: Coffee here is slightly on the expensive side but it is well worth it. The regular black coffee is smooth and I believe it tastes better than the sour coffee at Blue Bottle or other high end coffee shops. However, the employee didn't speak English that well though and couldn't answer my question about the pastries.
author: John E.

description: 4**** for the AWESOMENESS of the almond croissant! :D wow what a treat and how super cute is this coffee spot in the Fidi! Bookmarking this place for sure.
author: Tere C.

description: I would give zero stars to this place if I could. I got lunch from a food truck a few feet away from Coffee Cultures and decided to eat at the tables directly outside this coffee shop. The woman that was working came out and asked if we bought it from them, which we didn't. She told us that the seating was for customers only. I totally understand asking us to move if they needed the seating, but there was absolutely no one! There's only 4 tables outside and all we're completely open! The worst part about this is I buy coffee from them everyday, she didn't seem to care. There are plenty of other coffee shops I can give my money too.
author: Bree D.

description:
"Good morning! What can I get for you today?"

Can I please have a small cup of coffee and an Almond Croissant please?

"Sure thing. That'll be an arm and a leg."

Wait, excuse me?

"Oh, that'll be $7.50 for your coffee and croissant. Thanks!"
---
Coffee Cultures might as well charge me an arm and a leg. That was one expensive coffee outing.

To be fair, that was the best Almond Croissant I have ever had. Flakey on the outside like an unreliable friend, soft on the inside like Drizzy Drake. A crispy bite filled with a satisfying aroma of almond and sweetness.

But that and a small cup of coffee cost me a Subway Footlong, a bag of Lay's, and a McChicken on the side. To make matters worse, foodkid does not even have the palette to appreciate their cultured coffee (you can bet I added hella free organic Almond Milk to mine tho).

This is a fine coffee shop for a corner office baller. But just a little too pricey for the average cubicle warrior.
author: Ringo M.

description:
If you're looking for a place that's not crowded, this is the place to go. We came here when there was this other coffee shop that we originally went to was crowded. Our group was helped immediately. I was looking for something to order, but their menu was limited and didn't have my usual drink.

What surprised me was that they had ice cream here and it was tasty! If you have the chance, I highly recommend getting some.

If you're looking for a place to sit and relax, don't count on it as it's very limited and the premises of Coffee Cultures was small. This place was just a nice place to get a drink to go.
author: Aj C.

description: Pretty solid drinks here. I've passed by this place numerous times since I've worked in the area. I finally stopped by and I was very impressed. The spot is small, so my friend and I ordered our drinks to go. I ended up ordering a shake! Which seems random, but it had espresso in it and my hand to God it was probably the best espresso shake I've ever had. It was fantastic!. The customer service was really good here too. Both of the gentlemen behind the counter were really nice and answered my questions about the drink. I will definitely come back here again!
author: James R.

description:
Do you know that painting where the dogs are playing poker? Yeah, I love that one, too. Now that's real art. I'm waiting for that guy to paint what has to be the next in his series, dogs ordering lattes. That would be genius. And it should be set in Coffee Cultures because it's the kind of compact place that would likely attract a group of caffeine-addicted canines in long knit caps and sunglasses and covered from collar to tail in tattoos. That's the kind of surreal image I had in my head when I waited in line for their human counterparts to order their lattes.

Actually it's the baristas that have the tattoos. The customers are usually the snotty white-collar types who are besties with their egos and their smartphones. I find the baristas here quite friendly and not overly talkative (photo: http://bit.ly/1k70VK9). This is a point of contention at my nearby office where a few colleagues have found them rude and abrupt. Physician heal thyself. Maybe they should buy a dog painting. All I know is that I always get a very well-crafted Latte for $3.75 that I find quite satisfying (photo: http://bit.ly/1ngqR9q). The Counter Culture coffee they serve is generally smooth and rich.

But wait, there's more. Straus soft-serve frozen yogurt. Delicious and not overly creamy. Just two flavors, and I usually favor the vanilla with a touch of cardamom (photo: http://bit.ly/1jviTFF). That's the perfect afternoon snack when my egg salad sandwich from Lee's Deli just doesn't cut it. Did I mention it's less than a block away from my workplace? So obviously I'm swayed by the convenience factor and my ability to go with co-workers who want to huddle away from the office. Nothing like gossip and soft-serve. If you don't have anything nice to say, come walk with me to Coffee Cultures. You have to like dog paintings though.

COFFEE / FROYO - 4 stars...satisfying hot or cold
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...nice with high ceilings and travertine floors but tight quarters, usually need to take it to go
SERVICE - 4 stars...hey, they like me
TOTAL - 4 stars...dogs ordering lattes...love it
author: Ed U.

description: Friendly staff but when I pay $4.5 for a latte, I expect that it be worth the price.  Instead, taste wasn't better than a Starbucks latte and the temp was lukewarm at best.  Too many options around this area so def won't be returning.
author: Ben M.

description:
I BET YOU DIDN'T KNOW
(5 stars)

I'm going to let you in on a little secret that many probably have no idea about. Will I regret this? Likely. I'm stingy when it comes to finding hidden gems. They serve soft-serve and when they have it, get it. It's ridiculously good. You can choose vanilla, special (which is chocolate), or the swirl. I got the swirl because I LOVE THE BEST OF BOTH WORLDS. The vanilla has a nice creamy flavor and the chocolate has freckles of chocolate mixed in, every dabble the taste of chocolate can be taste. I can't believe I've discovered something so good at a coffee shop. 

Will I be back? YES. And it better not be out of stock.

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review.....
author: Jane A.

description:
Came here during early afternoon and got the latte and almond croissant. I passed by around 9:30am and it was packedddd. Like line around the block packed. So I came back at around 11am and there was a lot less people. 

    The latte was so-so, more on the milder side. The latte isn't as strong as I usually like it and there was quite a bit of foam on the top, but the true star here is the almond croissant! The almond croissant didn't taste like artificial almond flavoring and was quite tasty! They cut the croissant in half and a layer of sweet custard? Was added in. It's a pretty thin layer so it didn't make the croissant hard to bite into or too sweet! Also they dusted the top off with real sliced almonds and powered sugar! Really good and not that sweet! The thing though, was that the layers of the croissant was not that apparent inside (dough and lamination) and the texture is more on the softer side. I would say 3 stars. 

   Add one more star because the employees look like they know how to have fun! Laughing and joking, to each other, which made the whole place seem less bougie to me. Also, the selection music they had on was kewllll :)
author: Janet K.

description: Coffee Cultures was super convenient when I was working on Bush Street and the line, though always out the door of this tiny coffee shop, was always shorter than the bigger chain coffee shops and cafes surrounding it. The coffee was really good!
author: Rachel E.

description:
Hands down awesome. What makes it that much better than other good coffee shops around is how they have fro yo! I think the froyo selection changes but when I was there I got pumpkin spice. Would highly recommend. It was delicious and got me in the pumpkin spice aka autumn mood. 

I also got a mocha. Their latte art is on point and super pretty. The mocha was above average. 

They have somewhat limited seating by the window with stools to sit on. I sat down to do some reading and found it to be a good working spot. There's good lighting from outside and the noise level was a little louder than average but still conducive to working/reading (or good conversation if you want). 

Will be back if I'm in the area to try their coffee!
author: Julie L.

description:
They make the best vanilla almond milk latte!
The bostock is really good too if you like pastries in the morning. Starter Bakery provides their goodies, but the kouign amann is super small (compared to b. Patisserie). 

Just noticed that they have some lunch stuff. Can't wait to come back and grub on some tamales!
author: Lynnie P.

description:
Simple coffee shop that serves side lunch meals and frozen yogurt!

This is here for the convenience of being located in a working environment and people who feeds off the need for caffeine. 

It is a very small place and there is limited outside seating, but not much of a pleasant scene of lounging here.

There isn't quite anything wrong about this place nor impressive.  It just exists.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Coffee Cultures rules the Fidi. Coffee Bar watch out! Delicious cappuccino $3.25, lattes are $3.75. Two espresso options. The Espresso Toscano is delightful beyond words. I actually walked back in from outside to thank the friendly, bearded barista! They also have a cone-filter drip of the day that you can order.

Hmmm, these other reviewers, they say it's hipster. But I think it's just plain hip. The folks working there are just too nice to be considered "hipsters."
author: Ted R.

description:
BOOM! Another delicious Latte place. I'd describe this coffee shop as small in size, large in hipsterness and medium in personality. As you can tell by the yelp pictures, this place oozes hipster with a dash of professional since, after all, it's located in the Financial District. 

My small Latte (same size as a tall from Starbucks) was served very creamy with a nice foam layer for the more expensive than regular price of $4. This is also a $0.25 price increase from a 1/30/2015 Yelp review. I also disliked that there aren't different sizes to choose from. It was very above average (almost exceptional). I had a very difficult time grading this beverage because the Philz Coffee Truck is right down the block which is similarly priced.

I REALLY wanted to give this place 4 stars because they truly serve a 4 star latte but I can't justify the price, especially when Philz is right down the block. This is, however, a great alternative if you aren't willing to wait in line at a busy coffee shop.
author: Chris W.

description:
I am not a fan of this place.  I know it is very hipster/trendy to say "No" or "Nope" in this case to even the simplest customer requests, so the attitude of the cashier wasn't too surprising.  However the elitist attitude here was all tjat they could serve.  It is otherwise a coffe and muffin place in the lobby of an office building. Welcome to San Francisco.

There are plenty of high end espresso places in the City where you can be amused by the snobberry as you get a well prepared and well served drink.  This isn't one of them.
author: Michael M.

description:
Stumpled upon this place on my way to work and so glad I found it because its good! 

I also like the decor of the place and its always nice for coffee shops to offer simple syrup (starbucks, peets, and other chain coffee places need to get with the program! hard packet sugar - boo!!). 

Already planning on going back tomorrow to try out the mocha. Great refreshing addition to a financial district overrun with chains and mediocre food/coffee.

UPDATE: the mocha is meh. 
My favorite cup of coffee and mocha is Hollow in the Sunset district.
author: Cicely T.

description:
Good coffee.
Cool spot.
Minimal seating.
LOUDDDD music.
coffeecultures2014 (free wifi)
author: Shereen A.

description: I get that the people that work here are cooler than me. I'm ok with that. But do we really have to listen to insanely loud metal music before 8 am?  I'm here to get coffee..not check if I'm deaf.  Good pastries though. I don't need my hearing to taste them, which is a plus.
author: Alex S.

description:
One of the only hipster coffee places with a stamp card (!!!). 

I love the decor of this place, and the service is pretty fast. Great lattes. I tried the yogurt once and did not like it.. so I just won't order it again.
author: Angela L.

description:
Nice place, nice coffee. I didn't give 5* because they have limited options to eat and this is mainly a order to go place with no place to site. Only 4 o 5 spots in a shallow bar in the window.

I liked that this is not crowded. Actually I came here because the Blue Bottle was too crowded and noisy. Then I looked for options.

IMHO, Blue Bottle coffee is better but this it's order of magnitude above Starbucks or Peets.

I ate a Butter Croissant that was very good.
author: Juan C.

description:
Their coffee is spot on.  I've always had a pleasant experience here.  The espresso beverages are excellent; their baristas really know how to achieve the velvety texture of the milk and the counter culture coffee is great.  The drip seems to be brewed with an appropriate ratio of beans to water and it is on the medium to light side of the spectrum.

They have Jane pastries, which are really amazing.  I had a croissant this morning and it was by far one of the better croissants that I have had in the city.  It is not quite like a Tartine croissant, but it is light and crispy with well-defined layers.  You will not be disappointed with the croissant.

Their atmosphere is a little loud, but this is not really the spot where you'll hang out.  You'll grab your coffee and go.
author: Alexander P.

description: Coffee cultures has seriously good coffee. Great location right by the window. Limited seating but some nice bar stools by the window if you can grab one. I've really enjoyed their lattes and cappuccinos. The reason for 4-star is the customer service is inconsistent. It's either really good or really bad. That being said, I've been here many times and their espresso is really good. Great place to grab coffee to go.
author: Lisa O.

description:
I come here often due to working in the building.  The product is good.  I like the coffee here and find it to be as good as anywhere else short of maybe Blue Bottle but sometimes you just want a cup of coffee and not some concoction.  The baked goods are generally delicious too.  

The main problem here is that about 50% of the employees are actively trying to get you to not leave a tip.  I'm talking about general rudeness, messing up orders due to inattention.  The other 50% of the employees are great.  But it's impossible to give the place the 5 stars it might deserve otherwise based on the quality of the product and the nice, polite 50% of the staff.

I will continue to come here frequently due to the convenience factor but just wish the management could make politeness a requirement for hiring their employees.  That is not the case currently.
author: Chris Y.

description: OK coffee, good location. However, they play terrible music, all "fuc#" this and "nigg#" that. Not very pleasant and won't go back.
author: Adam T.

description: Very small coffee shop with some drink options (coffees, cold fruit drinks, hot cocoa) and just a few pastries and yogurt. I got a chocolate croissant and it is delicious but I couldn't get it toasted or warm because they don't have any heater. Fast service and good place if you're in a hurry or aren't looking for variety.
author: Sheereen S.

description: I come here out of convenience because it's across the street from my office. Coffee is good but holy where's the customer service? Everytime I enter, I'm never greeted and the employee always looks upset. I'm over here trying to bring myself back to life during my 3rd coffee break of the day and they're over there pouting and not saying hi. Way to bring the mood down even lower.
author: Christine G.

description:
Hmm, not too blown away by the latte I got ($3.75). 

I suppose it will do if you happen to be nearby, but with so many other places to get your fix of caffeine that are not named Starbucks or Peets, I'll pass on this place.
author: Viet N.

description: delicious affogato and scones - and amazing music. great way to start your day, or end it.
author: Kristina L.

description: Friendly baristas at 7:30am, fairly priced amazing coffee. They have a rewards system, too.
author: Charlotte A.

description:
Bought a vanilla latte a few weeks ago, and the barista made a regular one. I went back and asked for it to be remade, and the woman behind the counter drizzled some vanilla into the cup (which is NOT how to make a vanilla latte), and gave it back to me. It still tasted awful, so I went back a third time for a refund. The guy behind the counter told me "he couldn't give me a refund," which doesn't really make sense. My guess is that it was rush hour for them and they just wanted to get me out of there. He had the barista remake it for me a third time, but at that point, I had so much bad latte, I just threw it away. Try giving your customers refund if they specifically request it. 
I've stopped patronizing Coffee Cultures because they apparently "can't" (i.e. won't) give refunds. Very poor customer service, especially for the cost.
author: Berry B.

description:
From the outside it might appear unassuming, but head on in through the doors adorned with gorgeous typography and you're in for a treat. The espresso was bloody delicious and I appreciated that staff were happy to answer my questions about American coffee terms and espresso/milk ratio in drinks I wasn't so familiar with. 

I walked out with a Gibraltar which in my Melbourne coffee language translates to a magic or strong 3/4 latte. It too was excellent and I'm going to put it out there that these guys do the best coffee in the Financial district.
author: Tresna L.

description: In San Francisco on business and a colleague recommended Coffee Cultures to me.  Love this place.  Quick and friendly service and a super refershing iced blackeye.  They also have soft serve and pastries.  Conveniently located near the office I am making this a regular stop for my trip.
author: Scott S.

description:
Hipster Coffe in the fidi....FINALLY! No seriously, it's good and smooth. I generally prefer the Latte, and I have to say that the Latte at Coffee Cultures is very similar to Blue Bottle. I know...I said it... 

The baked goods looked great too. I couldn't help but snag a strawberry/chocolate chip muffin. There goes my carb-free diet...oh well...tomorrow is another day!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
I always see Coffee Cultures come up on my Yelp search when I'm looking for a place to get some caffeine, but it's a bit far from my office so I only finally got around to going yesterday and the 15 minute walk was well worth it. 

There isn't much seating, but a friend and I snagged a seat by the window. I tried some of my friend's iced coffee, which I was expecting to be sour as most iced coffee's are, but it was so smooth and not acidic at all! I was pleasantly surprised.

I got myself a swirl of the Vanilla and "Special Flavor" (which happened to be Chai) frozen yogurt, and it was SO GOOD. Definitely hit the spot on a warm sunny day. Considering that there are no (or close to zero) yogurt shops in FiDi, I'm so glad I found a place to get my froyo fix. The frozen yogurt wasn't too sweet, and it was a bit more on the icy side (rather than creamy), which is how I like my frozen yogurt. I'll definitely be back!
author: Joyce L.

description: A latte from Coffee Cultures sets you back $3.75, which is one of the most expensive lattes I've discovered in and around the Financial District. I do enjoy the "hipster" scene in a typically very sterile part of SF, and the pastries and other food options (which include homemade tamales!) certainly look delicious and fresh.  The menu board is simple, which makes ordering here efficient.  At $3.75, it's definitely not a steal of a deal, and the latte itself was good, but not something I could make a habit out of getting all the time.  Happy to have crossed this one off the list though, it was definitely a nice treat!
author: Lisa I.

description: I've walked by this place often on my way to work and finally stopped in today. The latte was delicious! Bonus, I didn't have to wait 20 mins for it like I would across the street at Blue Bottle. Will be back!
author: Melissa J.

description:
This FiDi newcomer is a welcome addition to the city coffee scene and I dig their espresso + frozen yogurt concept. Aesthetically, their historic storefront appears as though it'd be more at home in the Mission (Edison style light bulbs, industrial feel). The baristas are stylish and super sweet; I asked for a taste of the frozen yogurt yesterday and got way more than a mouthful. I'm definitely coming back for a swirl of both flavors (plain and TCHO chocolate - made with Straus Family Creamery yogurt).

I'm allergic to coffee but was a big fan of the hot chocolate. Can't wait to be a regular here!
author: Miriam W.

description: I love their lattes, they actually know how to make almond milk super frothy and good. Also, everyone who works here is the best. I came in today and noticed they had lunch items, and immediately someone working there was showing me the cold and hot options. The menu is actually quite big, soups, salads, tamales, etc. I really wanted oatmeal, and even though it was lunch time and they had put breakfast stuff away, they went back and made me some anyway. Of course its really good, and topped with flaxseeds, pumpkin seeds, and the oats are perfect. Best new breakfast/lunch spot to go with the best lattes.
author: Marisa L.

description:
I really wanted to love this place.

Read that it was opening on Thrillest and thought it would steal me away from CoffeeBar and the occasional trip to Starbucks.

Instead, I threw my cup in the garbage outside.

At first look, everything seemed great - frequent buyer cards, hipsters behind the bar and top quality coffee.

I ordered a 2% Chai and what I got was frothy spiced water.  

Yes - Frothy. Spiced. Water for $4.00 

The barista said the Chai was local and really great so I was sold but I could not have been more disappointed. I wish I was exaggerating but I dumped the so called Chai into the trash outside and cannot recommend this place to anyone based on my experience today.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Wow, best coffee I've found in the financial district.  I especially love their iced coffee.  I usually prefer cold brew iced coffee, but theirs is just fantastic!

The only reason it lacks a fifth star is for lack of seating or bathrooms.  (You have to go next door and trade your ID for a key to the buildings bathroom.)  Also only about 5 stools inside to sit on, yet seems to have enough standing space for several tables.
author: Greg B.

description:
I've been exploring coffee shops near my new office, and Coffee Cultures caught my eye. They have the artisan, hipster vibe that usually means you can expect a good cup of coffee. This definitely was the case! They have almond milk (a huge plus), so I got a large almond milk latte. 

I had eyed their pastry case, but was trying to be good... I sat down with my latte and was reading my book, but couldn't squelch my craving for an almond croissant. I gave in, and got the last one (the girls in line hated my guts...I heard them voicing their disappointment). It was AMAZING. $4.20 is expensive for a pastry, but it was pretty big and really good, so I couldn't complain too much. 

I'd definitely give Coffee Cultures a try if you're in the area. They also played metal which I thought was a nice change from the typical jazz :)
author: Grace M.

description:
Great coffee place in FiDi - probably one of the best! This place is a little out of the way for me because I don't pass by here at all on the way to work, but sometimes if I really am dying from lack of coffee, I will leave home extra early and detour here for my Americano. They have great coffees, great staff, and even offer almond milk for those who are lactose intolerant or like your lattes extra fancy. 

They also offer frozen yogurt, great assortment of pastries, and a frequent buyer card (that I seem to have lost :'( )
author: Jeanette S.

description: Coffee Cultures is a small, hipster coffee shop with great coffee. This spot is more for your quick coffee stop before work as there are only 4 or 5 seats inside and a few tables in front. I've come here to do a bit of work before, but I was forced to sit outside because people like to sit and chat inside while waiting for their coffee. I really enjoy their cappuccino, but it's on the pricier side for a cappuccino (but hey this is FiDi we're talking about)
author: Estelle C.

description:
I love a place that not only serves good coffee, but serves good knowledge, too. I walked in for a cup of joe, and asked one of the baristas for advice on adjusting my company's espresso grinder, which has been on the fritz. The chap gave me step by step instructions as to how to make the machine do my bidding with no sense of making me feel like a nincompoop for asking/not knowing in the first place. 

Funny enough, after this exchange, even with an adjusted grinder, I'm more likely to come back.
author: Alicia O.

description:
I'm sorry, you guys.

I came in today and realized my grave, grave error. There is, in fact, pour over coffee at this fine establishment. Yes, it is excellent. The only problem with my recent visit that spurred my previous review was simple - I apparently lack the ability to read.

Today I went in, saw the barista crafting pour overs, ordered one, and it is very, very good. I got a blueberry & cream cheese pastry to go with it, which is very filling and tasty.

Coffee Cultures is a welcome, needed addition to the coffee scene in my corner of the Financial District. I'll keep coming back.
author: Kevin C.

description: Maybe we came in on an off day bc everyone is giving great reviews.  Super bad attitudes and bad service.  We waited over 10 minutes for a pour over coffee and there was ONE other person there.  The girl obviously forgot to make it but never said anything to us.  The coffee was just ok.  Blue Bottle is across the street so I'd rather go there.
author: Karen L.

description:
Simple pleasures of coffee and tea
make this place a great place to be

Their Chai Tea Lattes are not instantly sweet
Get a peanut butter and jelly brioche, they are not a dieter's treat

There are places to sit inside and out
The espresso machine is so pretty 
and the staff is friendly and deserves a shout out

They open super early if you need your fix to wake up
Even if it requires more than just a cup
author: Kristi G.

description:
I was really excited about this place, considering they make their own yogurt. My coworker and I went in and asked for samples, just in case, and i'm so glad that we did. The chocolate had a good texture, but the taste was too cacao-ey for me. I would have preferred a richer chocolate flavor, but it tasted more like carob to me. The regular has an icier texture, but I liked the flavor of it a lot more, it was really light, and just a little bit tart. The two together was probably the best for me, but even then, it didn't make me really want to get a full cup because I was so unimpressed by them in general. 

The only topping that they currently have is granola. I felt bad for leaving and not ordering anything, but I just knew that I wouldn't want a full cup of the yogurt that I had just tasted. I'll be back again to try their pastries, as those looks pretty amazing. Not much of a coffee drinker, so I thought this would be the best blend for me to meet friends, who always want coffee.
author: Annie S.

description:
Espresso was on point. I think I might be falling in love with this place. Is that allowed? Hope i dont get stuck in the friend zone.  

But really, Great staff, great coffee, easy access and fast service.
author: JJ Z.

description:
After blindly slapping at the nagging, harsh alarm clock and drowsily stumbling to the bathroom to make preparations before a ray of light has cracked the horizon, slow realization sets in yet again that there is no time for breakfast. Incessant stomach grumbles accompany each lethargic step towards the dingy bus stop littered with remnants of wind-swept trash. Once crammed into the trembling, nauseating shuttle with dozens of riders wearing vacant stares, a resigned sigh precedes premonitions of the doom waiting at the faraway desk.
 
Then, a desperate mental foray accidentally rediscovers the oasis of COFFEE CULTURE'S ALMOND CROISSANT.
 
Anticipating the crispy, flaky croissant exterior enlivens half-dead taste buds; imagining the slightly underbaked and tender doughy innards whispers reassurance to a yearning stomach; and remembering the copious dusting of snowy powdered sugar causes a noticeable skip in heartbeat. A choice between flavorful, familiar dark coffee brew, potently biting iced coffee or strongly layered mocha provides a supportive backdrop for the palatial pastry.
 
Sunshine slowly but surely begins to seep in through the windshield as the bus hurtles towards a more promising outlook for the day, reintroducing color, warmth, and hope.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Just got coffee from here this morning. I love the location! My boyfriend works in the building and the muni drops us off in front so this place is extremely convenient! 

I love the retro/classy vibe this place gives off. The cashier uses an ipad and they give stamp cards. A mix between an asian boba place and a contemporary coffee cafe. 

I'm normally a chai the latte kinda girl so I got that. But I eventually traded drinks with my boyfriend because his vanilla latte was DELICIOUS - better than my nonfat chai. 

I just wish their regular cup of joe was cheaper. It's $2.50 for a regular cup. Starbucks is cheaper than that! I will definitely come back to this place and plan to fill up my stamp card - I'm obsessed with those things!
author: Mimi V.

description:
Gorgeous dimly-lit wooden interior and unassuming, hipster atmosphere! I felt like a million bucks just having the privilege to wait for my order.

Wait, this is a coffee shop; I should be talking about the coffee. Well, I remember that I cringed when my bill came out to $5+ for a small mediocre mocha. Guess I'm not made for this high-baller coffee life - back to Starbucks for my afternoon pick-me-ups.

Service was excellent though, hence the 4 stars - definitely didn't get a snobby vibe from my barista/cashier (unlike other coffee shops cough cough).
author: Aileen L.

description: Solid coffee spot in Financial District. They do it 3rd wave coffee style with the fancy milk art work in the espresso drinks. The cappuccino is excellently prepared with their La Marzocco machine. The place itself is beautifull put together though not really conducive for sitting down for coffee -- more for to go for maybe working at the bar counter.
author: Victor W.

description:
Located on Bush St, keepin' it real cool on that kush, 
deep in the street of FiDi, real hustlers tryna get that benji, 
no tweekers here, just Twitchers on caffein, 
limited seating at the bar, best bet is outside with a trench,
baristas, tattoos, woodgrain, what more do you want, 
latte art, tulip keepin' two hearts stack, 
soft serve, OG Straus milk and probiotic, 
this place is mad decent for a cup of coffee, 
prime location for people watchin' and smokin' a pack of cig, 
if you ain't about that culture, you ain't about that life
author: Roy C.

description: Overpriced and snobby.  AND I'm not sure why they don't have more pastries stocked - they seem to be out of everything by 10am.  You blow!
author: Janet J.

description:
Review is only for the soft serve....

It was awful, I've never had soft serve this unappealing before. Ended up tossing most of it out because it wasn't even worth powering through to validate the spend. Maybe this is some fancy, SF version of soft serve but I like good, old-fashioned soft serve.

$4 per cup, don't waste the money.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Amazing third wave, pour over coffee right on my way to work. Small location- grab and go. There are some stools along the window but it's not a place to camp out with a laptop. 

Small pastry selection, but they always have a gluten-free raspberry muffin that is absolutely great!
author: Nicole H.

description: Unfriendly service, once I finished my drink they rushed me to empty the table...won't be coming back
author: Bahar R.

description: I've only been here once, and I'm sure this place is normally great. But my first experience was such a turn off, I don't think I'll be coming back. With the price you pay for a simple drip coffee, I was a little let down by the fact I have to pour it myself. The coffee had a great taste, until I hit the end of my cup. I got a mouthful of coffee grinds and when I popped the top off, a good amount of it was stuck on the side. Overall, it wasn't the best experience.
author: Elton M.

description:
In a good location, right across from my office actually! They use really nice beans, (counter culture coffee) but I'm afraid they don't quite do the beans justice. 

I've had a doppio espresso, and a "Vietnamese iced coffee". The doppio was okay but not very smooth, and the Vietnamese iced coffee did not taste so at all. It tasted like regular iced coffee with milk. 

It's a cool, hip place, definitely. but it's not really making my list of shops with good coffee.
author: Fion L.

description: I love this place! I got the iced latte and the coffee is so smooth and flavor is wonderful. Highly reccommend you give this place a try. One of my favorite coffee shops in fidi.
author: Ally T.

description:
So...people will talk about the coffee here.  Yeah, that was good...

But did you know that they had AWESOME tamales here???  I love the green chili tomales here...what the heck are they doing at this coffee place?!  Smokey, moist, grainy, and perfectly cooked chicken.  Yeah, DAMN good tomales.

So don't just get coffee here - get some tamales too!
author: Mark M.

description:
These guys are totally rude and the coffee was awful. 

Their espresso wasn't dialed at all and tasted like bitter tar juice. Was mistaken by the good reviews.
author: Eunice K.

description: Great little coffee shop. The lattes are awesome here. Staff is very friendly, and the lines move pretty quickly.
author: Brenden K.

description:
I got the Vietnamese Iced Coffee and really, really wanted to like it. But all that remained was disappointment and over 8 ounces of bland, watered down "coffee" that ended up in the trash can...

I was blinded by the raved reviews once again. Peet's would have been better.
author: Maggi K.

description:
5 stars for everything other than the service. There's no excuse for baristas with attitude, and considering the rent this place must go for, I'm hoping the owners go give everyone a "pep talk" about how to treat customers.  Pro tip: you are supposed to make us think you actually care remotely about us and somewhat enjoy giving us coffee, not make us think we are interrupting your discussion of the latest Instagram feed you subscribed to.

Anyhow, the coffee is outstanding, among the best of SF - easily up there with Blue Bottle, Ritual, and Four Barrel.  The location is perfect for anyone in FIDi, and it's priced appropriately with high quality coffee.

BTW - this is not a "cafe" to sit around in - get your warm beverage and get out, there's no lounging here.  Also, not for anyone in a mega-rush to get their caffeine fix.  You should be able to clear at least 2 levels of Angry Birds while waiting for your cup a' joe.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
It's unfortunate because the coffee here is actually very good.  The main problem is the pretentious staff.  While this is not my everyday coffee haunt, I do come here every so often and never had any problems before.   I guess today the guy woke up on the wrong side of the bed? Who knows.  But in any case, with the plethora of other decent coffee places now in the FiDi, I will vote with my wallet and take my business elsewhere.  No need for attitude - I get plenty of that in the office!

Oddly enough, when I went back to my usual place, the barista was saying how they know a few guys who work at Coffee Cultures and also said they they were known to be snobby so I'm not the only one!
author: Tomy T.

description:
This place is awesome. From the moment you walk in line till you leave. The people who work here are friendly, nice and just cool. They even remember your drink even though there's always a line. 

They have your typical drinks - latte, Americano, cappuccino, etc. But they also have a great assortment of pastries.y favorite is this lime and coconut muffin. The almond croissant is also not bad. 

They do really establish a culture of
Coffee lovers. The space is great and they have a little bar-type sitting area with a window facing outside where you can read a newspaper or a book. Each morning I try to stop in and hang out before heading to the office. 

The people who come here are great as well. I've met a few people and have also run into some familiar faces. I recommend this place to anyone who considers the self a coffee lover!!
author: Josh F.

description:
Just got a hot chocolate. It's not hot. It's not chocolatey . So wtf did I just buy. 
Yuk
Yuk
Yuk 



Yuk





Yuk 







Feel like I just got robbed.
author: Emma F.

description:
Coffee Cultures is one of the few places in the area where you can enjoy Counter Culture Coffee, one of the best roasters in the nation. That said, I make a morning stop here every so often and the guys pull me a perfect gilbraltar every time. I must say that it's one of the few places in FiDi where you can get specialty coffee, perfected. These guys know what they're doing. They also source delightful pastries - my favorite is the almond croissant. 

Also a plus that these guys remember me and my coffee mug and know exactly what I'm ordering! 

If you want to start your morning right, start it here.
author: David O.

description:
Once upon a time I worked as a barista and then a cafe manager for six some years. I like to kid myself that this means I know one or two things about what makes not only a good cup of coffee but also a most welcoming atmosphere. Coffee Cultures has both. 

A few months ago I ran into a barista friend near my non-cafe place of employment (Financial District office job), and he told me he was in the area working at Coffee Cultures. Of course, I promised to come check it out, and I was not disappointed. After my first latte here, I texted my friend to say, "You have introduced me to the nectar of life." The coffee is fabulous; the baristas know what they are doing; and best of all, they do it with good humor and general loveliness. Despite being in a high traffic spot, they remember individuals -- like myself ::blushes:: And they joke about saving me a savory pastry or tease me about being late for work, as they hand me a cup of flawless latte art. 

Sad news is: I'm leaving my office job around the corner. While I won't be stopping in bi-weekly, a visit to Coffee Cultures may just motivate me to trip into the cold corporate heart of San Francisco more than every once in awhile.
author: Bri N.

description: More decent coffee places in the Financial District = thumbs up from me. Wish they had a lil more seating, but otherwise a good cup of brew.
author: Mel G.

description:
I have been waiting for something like this. I think I'm always looking for something like this. In other reviews of coffee shops in SF that put people, the depth of coffee, the connection across cultures forward in their work, I've waxed on & on about it. Here is another shop that is doing just that. And you know what... it may be even more important because of its location. In the austere, de-personalized Financial District of Sansome & Bush, we now have a business that cares about the personable relationship of coffee & people, & you & the shop. The architecture of cities plays a deep role in how people interact with each other. We've heard the sanguine story before: rote business models before best practices of people. In the changing climate of work, we're a new group of people who can remain heartfelt in the face of business, even financial business. 

The words that come to mind of this place is: luxe, warming, courageous, fun!, and loving the cups of coffee that come out of here. A gold spoon served with their espresso was one thing. The next... a raspberry. Yes, a raspberry. A pairing. Coffee is a drink just like wine. It's fermented in its process often, and fruits / food can bring out a whole new level of character. 

Look, you can take it as stand offish & snobby, but damn if you don't see how people love their craft & get way into everything. That's how this city works: we get way into everything we do, & out comes opinions. We have opinions here -- that's how this website works -- and coffee, through centuries, has incited even goats to have an opinion on how to live. If you're into ritual, conversations, caffeine, and fun -- pure luxurious but affordable fun -- this is it. Right, smack, in the middle of the Financial District. Heel clicks will follow.
author: Jon A.

description:
What once was a coffee desert has now become a coffee oasis. Coffee Cultures is one of the several places serving very nice espresso drinks.

Coffee Cultures is the most consistently good espresso in the financial district. They serve Counter Culture coffees and espressos, and they do so quite well. They have one decaf espresso and two regular espressos. At the moment one is a single origin and the other is a blend. I imagine these rotate around to other things Counter Culture is roasting, but I can't say so for certain.

The drinks are always quite flavorful. The milk is done quite well, and while I wouldn't say they get as much out of their espresso as Ritual, this is a really solid stop. The art is always quite nice.

The only thing is I'd wish they would get either LevelUp or Square (I'd prefer LevelUp). That way I wouldn't have to sign receipts any more.
author: Erik S.

description: The place is packed during morning coffee but a great place to stop by after lunch for a latte or macchiato along with some of their yogurt. Prices are comparable to the rest of FiDi.
author: Linda L.

description: There's an explosion of new coffee spots on this corner but CC remains my go to spot for good old fashion lattes. They're not going to have your Starbucks style over the top sweet drinks here. Just smooth pick me up lattes made perfect every time. No crazy lines to order. No super long waits for coffee to be made.
author: Judy K.

description:
Holy CRAP their caramel macchiato was strong for me! I've made it my mission to debunk any myths out there that Starbucks rules the coffee & tea realm and Coffee Cultures is definitely on my list of places that outshine Starbucks. 

Had the caramel macchiato and for those who don't got their coffee game right, it is NOT as sweet and milky and fatty as Starbucks makes it. Coffee Cultures makes it strictly as an espresso that has milk foamed to the top, yummm! 

I personally feel like they were a bit burned or had a really smokey taste to it. I would like to come back and try the other beverages in the near future! 

Just be sure to come by early bc there will be a line but I never had to wait longer than 7 - 10 minutes.
author: Jo L.

description:
Espresso Meh. yogurt Yum!

Love that i can finally have an espresso with something other than a butter lathered pastry. I absolutely love frozen yogurt because I feel as if it is the perfect healthy dessert. So when I found that there was a place where you could get both coffee and Straus milk yogurt I was all in! The espresso was way too acidic for my taste. Maybe it's just preference but I could barely even swallow this espresso without cringing my whole entire face. The yogurt on the other hand was delicious! It was not as heavy and creamy as the yogurts you would usually get at Pinkberry or Yogurtland which is why I loved it so much! The price is also fair considering the quality of the yogurt and the amount you get. I will definitely be back for the yogurt!
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
Coffee Culture is delightful! The baristas are on their A game when it comes to brewing and serving. The space is beautiful! Rare knowledge + great service + good coffee beans = happy me.

Thanks Coffee Cultures!
author: Demitri G.

description:
ALMOND MILK!!!

So stoked a boutique-like coffee shop opened up near my office. Coffee Cultures keeps it simple by sticking to the basics with the menu. No fancy Frappachinos or complicated orders to deal with, just coffee, lattes, capps, mochas, tea, etc....

I am even more thrilled that they offer Almond Milk verses the crowd favorite of Soy. Soy if not that great for you (isoflavones, fat), and I love how almond milk gives it a sweetness kick without the calories sugar has!

And, of course, their coffee is strong, flavorful and great!
author: Meredith M.

description:
This place is really chill. Great seating for people watching. The coffee is good, but not great. But it's better than Starbucks. 

The pastries are really good! Especially their cream cheese Danish, however I wouldn't get anymore than the half unless you are able to share but even then id share the half.

The bathroom is clean and the service is great :)
author: Matthew M.

description:
This is easily the best coffee place in San Francisco, both from the quality of products and the service.

I work in the building and get 1-2 cups of coffee daily from Coffee Cultures along with some amazing baked goods they get from local bakeries. They are constantly serving new and original coffees that are in season and are not only knowledgeable of how each is roasted and its history, but they are also passionate about their product and what they do.

I've noticed a couple posts about the customer service not being too great. While everybody can have a bad day once in a while, I have never walked in feeling unwelcome or a sense of hostility. On the contrary, I know that whenever I go to get my coffee I can have a great conversation with the staff ranging from the new coffee that they brought in or how to brew it, to sports or weekend plans. 

The baked products are unreal. Maybe a little unhealthy, but seriously unreal. Whether its the brioche buns with different fillings, the blueberry white chocolate muffins, or the pumpkin bacon cheddar quiche, you really can't go wrong.

This is a one of a kind cafe - While small, you can still sit inside at their counter or at their outdoor tables.

Highly recommended!!!!
author: Tyler T.

description: Counter Culture Coffee in FiDi of San Francisco. Very small place, probably not the place you want to try to set your laptop up and work or to meet someone. Staff was very well trained and coffee is excellent. They do have 4? tables outside but it is very busy / noisy...
author: Michael P.

description: The Frozen Yogurt tag is a lie. There is no Frozen Yogurt here. They do have a soft serve ice cream machine with vanilla, chocolate and a swirl, if you're into that sort of thing.
author: miguel v.

description:
Finally, they're open! The coffee is really good; I've had the latte, and it's just strong enough without any bitterness. Pastries are my weakness, and their selection definitely caught my eye. They have cookies from what tastes like Anthony's, an interesting almond croissant-Texas toast hybrid, and almond croissants with crispy bits oozing out--definitely what I'm trying next!

One thing, like many other hip coffee places, they don't put prices on the items in the glass case, so be prepared to spend around $2.50 for a cookie and $3+ for a pastry.
author: Nicole L.

description: They serve Counter Culture. Had a shot of espresso here, which was pulled very well.  I really appreciated the fact that the barista waited to pull my shot so that it wouldn't sit there.
author: Mindy C.

description:
Coffee Cultures is the de facto coffee place for my coworkers to get coffee, so I've gotten a lot of lattes from this place. It's a small shop, not much seating and not really a sit and work and chill out kind of place IMO. 

While pricey in the grand scheme of coffee, it's on par with other establishments of the hipster variety. The lattes at Coffee Cultures is what ruined Starbucks for me forever. They are so smooth and creamy and overall delicious, and often comes with some nifty latte art. 

I am not a huge fan of their normal brews; I find it acidic. I think that is more a a reflection of my own tastes than their coffee, since I've tried other hipster coffee and found that it tastes similar. 

Overall this is a great place for your daily dose of caffeine. They have a loyalty stamp card where for every 10 drinks you buy you get one free.  They also do frozen yogurt, which I haven't tried yet, but it's definitely on my list!
author: Ming L.

description: Nice cappuccino and today's brew. Unfortunately not much space to sit around, yet if you are lucky (and weather is nice), they have few tables outside on the pavement of Bush street.
author: Modesta N.

description: Mmm...almond milk latte and chocolate crossaint to start the morning.  Yes please!!  Perfect little spot to grab a cup before school/work/wherever you are going.  Not a great spot to hang out since they do have limited seating inside.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Can't get a better latte.

Originally wanted an almond milk latte, but since they were out, went with nonfat. I was very pleasantly surprised by how smooth and delicious it was. No sourness, and no need to add any sugar or flavorings. 

Can't wait to come back and try the straus creamery (the best local creamery) yogurt. 

Decor is nice and modern with trendy typography and people working. FYI, not a great place for working or chatting with people as there are only a few seats that face the window.

New favorite spot for coffee downtown!!! Giving Philz a run for its money.
author: Nanette W.

description:
Really cool atmosphere, not too hipster but the right amount. They do a lot of different options, like your standard coffee and coffee of the day. I came here after lunch so I wanted something on the sweeter side and saw the option for a espresso milkshake. No expectations, I could already taste the spices associated with the espresso beans, hints of cinnamon, not overly milky, and espresso grounds on the bottom to chew on. 

There is plenty of outdoor seating. And the service is really quick. I really like the vibe that this place gives out, and definitely made for a more modern coffee shop experience. If you have time give this place a try.
author: Matt M.

description: I didn't think the coffee (I got a mocha) was anything special. It could have been warmer. I like that they use an iPad for ringing us up. It was quick. Beware some people love this place there's a line in the morning. The pastries all looked soo yummy; especially the blueberry white chocolate muffin but I refrained. Kinda regret it but I don't even want to know how many calories. Maybe I'll come back on a cheat day!
author: Ameera D.

description:
They have AMAZING Bostock pastry as well as the berry danish. Danish has fresh blueberries and nice balance among pastry to custard ratio. Custard is also nicely done.  Bostock is a must try! 
Both are large, fresh, delicious and undeniably craving-ly good! Coffee is great as well. Wish they had a bit more sitting space, but that's a minor wish.
author: Busy P.

description:
Lattes are super creamy and sweet. I like that they have the option of almond milk. Americanos are also good. I'd skip the mocha. I was really excited to see they use tcho chocolate but it was so light I couldn't even taste it. It was also pricey at $4.50. The cultures part of their name is for their froyo! The consistency is a little more icy and light. I tried the chocolate flavor and it was good. Sweet but also had a good bitterness to it, also made with tcho chocolate.

Don't forget to grab a punch card!
author: Alice J.

description: Just what the doctor ordered!!!! So glad this is here. The manager is super nice and cool. Like better than Coffee Bar.  Wish there was a little seating.
author: Andrew K.

description:
There is nothing that compares to this. Amazing. 
My go-to coffee shop. The one and only. 
They know how to make a long black! Saviours! 

The staff are amazing, always so friendly. 

Australian certified.
author: Kristy B.

description: Wow! These guys are so much cooler than coffee bar (sorry) & a ton more friendly & their South Carolina coffee is nothing short of delicious! Love this spot!
author: Nicole E.

description:
Coffee Cultures is on my list for good espresso in the FiDi -- second to Blue Bottle but better than Coffee Bar. I always get really friendly service, and the people watching, despite limited real estate to do so, is excellent. The crowd that frequents this establishment seems to be a combination of suits, hipsters, and techies (or if you hit the jackpot all three of those combined in one).

Also, they have Anthony's Cookies. If espresso + Anthony's Cookies doesn't make you want to go, you're probably dead inside and probably didn't even cry during the movie Up.
author: Claire C.

description:
Although I'm not a rich man, although I don't work downtown, I still take the express bus. Its the fastest way for a Berkeley-bound student to get to BART, and helps me to avoid the Lovecraftian horrors of the 38 at rush hour. If it weren't for these businessmen's busses, I would never have come to Coffee Cultures.

For Coffee Cultures, location is everything: adjacent to the Bush and Sansome stop, outside the lobby of the 255 Bush building, right in the way of the caffeine-starved zombies of the Financial District. Inside, the space is trendily modern in all the right ways: walls painted a trendy dove-grey are set off by splashes of textured wallpaper, lights in spheres are suspended from a high ceiling, a logo designed to put on t-shirts is subtly (and not so subtly) worked into every available surface. Hardwood shelving holds rows of clean white and translucent glass vessels, contrasting with the white stone counter and burnished chrome tools of the barrista's trade. To the side a small seating area features stools stolen from your high-school's chemistry lab and big picture windows opening out to Bush Street, reminding customers that the distance between the cozy space of coffee cultures and the expansive horror of their workdays is just a plate glass window away. Music plays loudly, the triumphant chords and soaring melodic lines and vapid lyrics of modern "indie" corporate-rock pump people up for their workday, or remind them that it could be so much worse, they could have to spend the day working in a place that played shitty music and dished up caffeine to pissed-off businessmen and women. 

Although the propinquity of Coffee Culture's location is more notable then their coffee, they do a pretty good job nevertheless.
